label: art_00002
text:
The Hunters in the Snow
 　          \0K           Pieter Brueghel the Elder, 1565\0d
 　　　　　　  　　　  　　\0KOil on wood panel\0d

label: art_00002_1
text:
A landscape artist from the late
Renaissance period, Brueghel was
known as the "Peasant Artist."\0\0He earned the title for depicting
scenes from common peasant life,
such as the moment captured here.\0\0Note the contrast between the
weary hunters and the people
frolicking below on icy ponds.

label: art_00006
text:
Beauty Looking Back
                  \0KHishikawa Moronobu, 17th century\0d
　　　　　　　　  　　　　 　　\0KColor on silk\0d

label: art_00006_1
text:
A hand-painted piece by Hishikawa
Moronobu, an artist known for
popularizing the ukiyo-e style.\0\0This stirring painting depicts a
fashionable woman glancing back
over her shoulder.

label: art_00010
text:
The Milkmaid
                  　　\0KJohannes Vermeer, circa 1658\0d
  　　　　 　　　　　　　　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00010_1
text:
This piece earned Vermeer the
nickname "Master of Light" thanks to
its exquisite contrast and depth.\0\0Vermeer painted this masterpiece at
only 25 years of age. Many note that
it is surprisingly small in real life.

label: art_00014
text:
The Blue Boy
                   　   \0KThomas Gainsborough, 1770\0d
  　　　　　　　 　　　 　　　\0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00014_1
text:
Gainsborough was known for his
innovative use of colors in his
traditional portraits, like this one.\0\0Although he preferred painting
landscapes, his portraits would be
the defining work of his career.

label: art_00018
text:
Mona Lisa
                     　\0KLeonardo da Vinci, circa 1503\0d
  　　　　　　　　  　　　　 　\0KOil on poplar\0d

label: art_00018_1
text:
The world's most famous smile. It's
said that da Vinci kept this painting
for himself until the very end...\0\0Given its power to beguile visitors
all these years later, it's easy to
see why.

label: art_00020
text:
Apples and Oranges
           　　　 　　  \0KPaul Cézanne, circa 1899\0d
  　　　 　　　　　　　　 　　\0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00020_1
text:
This still life is known to have
inspired the work of many other
artists, including Pablo Picasso.\0\0Rather than trying to recreate an
image, Cézanne captured the beauty
of shapes from many angles.\0\0With this work, Cézanne draws on
both the atmosphere of his subjects
and the spirit of its beholders.

label: art_00024
text:
Lady with an Ermine
                  　　\0KLeonardo da Vinci, circa 1490\0d
  　　　　　　　　　 　　  \0KOil on wood panel\0d

label: art_00024_1
text:
One of only four portraits of women
painted by da Vinci, one of which is
the "Mona Lisa."\0\0Some believe that the "ermine" is not
actually an ermine, but rather a white
ferret!

label: art_00028
text:
Girl with a Pearl Earring
　　                  \0KJohannes Vermeer, circa 1665\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00028_1
text:
Also known as "Girl with a Turban,"
this piece uses ultramarine paint,
which was expensive at the time.\0\0It seems the expense was worth it, as
the vivid blue colors draw the eye
and help make the piece a classic.\0\0The only question is... Is that a real
pearl earring? Or something else...

label: art_00032
text:
The Birth of Venus
                  　  　\0KSandro Botticelli, circa 1485\0d
　　　　　　　　 　  　　\0KTempera on canvas\0d

label: art_00032_1
text:
A painting of the Roman goddess
Venus riding a scallop shell after
being born in the ocean.\0\0The name Botticelli is said to actually
be a nickname given to the artist's
brother, who was built like a barrel.\0\0Why this nickname was transferred
between siblings is a mystery lost
to the ages.

label: art_00034
text:
The Clothed Maja
                 　　\0KFrancisco de Goya, circa 1805\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00034_1
text:
It is said that this painting is a more
discreet version of an earlier work
known as "The Nude Maja."\0\0It is also known that Francisco de
Goya was quite popular in his own
time. Could these facts be related?\0\0A third, unrelated fact—the word
"maja" refers to a "stylish young
lady of Madrid."

label: art_00038
text:
Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji
     The Great Wave off Kanagawa
  \0KKatsushika Hokusai, circa 1831, Woodblock print\0d

label: art_00038_1
text:
The signature piece of ukiyo-e artist
Katsushika Hokusai, painted as part
of a series when he was in his 60s.\0\0Although it is dubbed "Thirty-Six
Views," he eventually added 10 more
to make 46 in total.

label: art_00042
text:
Summer
                    \0KGiuseppe Arcimboldo, circa 1563\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00042_1
text:
A curious portrait by Giuseppe
Arcimboldo, an Italian painter from
the late 16th century.\0\0It doesn't take a particularly sharp
eye to see that the entire portrait
is composed of fresh produce.

label: art_00044
text:
The Gleaners
       　　　     \0KJean-François Millet, 1857\0d
   　　　　　　　　　　　 　　\0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00044_1
text:
The signature piece from Millet, who
was known for depicting the lives of
commoners in the 19th century.\0\0Notice the abundant crops visible in
the background relative to the
meager wheat remaining for workers.\0\0This art served as social commentary
in a time of great inequality.

label: art_00046
text:
A Bar at the Folies-Bergère　　　
　   　                  \0KÉdouard Manet, circa 1882\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　  　 　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00046_1
text:
Close inspection of the mirror behind
this painting's subject reveals many
mysteries and paradoxes...\0\0In fact, the painting is based on
multiple perspectives, which explains
the unusual placement of some items.\0\0Sadly, this is Manet's last major work.
He passed away a year after it was
complete, at age 51.

label: art_00048
text:
The Fifer
                      　　　　\0KÉdouard Manet, 1866\0d
  　　　　　　　　 　　　　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00048_1
text:
One of Manet's earlier works, this
painting depicts a young flautist
dressed in military uniform.\0\0Manet's works are notable for their
lack of linear perspective and strong
color contrast.\0\0These attributes led some to call him
"The Father of Impressionism" and
make comparisons to Vélazquez.\0\0Fun fact—flautists can determine
what note the boy is playing just
by studying the painting closely.

label: art_00050
text:
Sunflowers
 　　                 \0KVincent van Gogh, circa 1888\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　　 　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00050_1
text:
Van Gogh painted this piece when he
moved to the south of France in
search of more vibrant colors.\0\0Yellow was Van Gogh's favorite color,
and he made seven paintings that
featured sunflowers during this time.

label: art_00052
text:
The Sower
                  　\0KJean-François Millet, circa 1850\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00052_1
text:
Millet painted this piece of a farmer
sowing wheat seeds in a field after
moving to the countryside from Paris.\0\0If the piece reminds you of Van
Gogh, that's likely because Van
Gogh himself was inspired by it!

label: art_00056
text:
The Night Watch
                      　　 \0KRembrandt van Rijn, 1642\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00056_1
text:
This masterpiece, painted by 17th
century Dutch artist Rembrandt,
depicts a military gathering.\0\0At the time, portraits usually showed
their subjects standing still. So this
was a leap forward in technique.\0\0For many years, art scholars thought
the painting was set at night, but a
restoration revealed a dark varnish.\0\0We can now see the dynamic poses
and lighting as they were meant to
be seen—in the daytime!

label: art_00066
text:
Ōtani Oniji the 3rd as Yakko Edobei
                   　　　　\0KTōshūsai Sharaku, 1794\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　　  \0KWoodblock print\0d

label: art_00066_1
text:
A print from the mid-Edo period by
Tōshūsai Sharaku depicting a famous
actor of the time.\0\0Sharaku made roughly 140 ukiyo-e
prints in his career, even though it
only spanned around 10 months!

label: art_00068
text:
Liberty Leading the People
 　　　　                  \0KEugène Delacroix, 1830\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00068_1
text:
Painted by leading 19th century
Romantic artist Delacroix in the
same year as a French revolution.
The woman in the center is often
mistaken for Joan of Arc, but she is
actually the fictional "Marianne."

label: art_00072
text:
Las Meninas
  　　                  \0KDiego Velázquez, circa 1656\0d
  　　　　　　　　　　　 　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_00072_1
text:
This famous piece by Velázquez, who
served the Spanish court, shows us
something about perspective.\0\0It depicts a young princess with her
"ladies-in-waiting." The artist himself
is seen to the left.\0\0The king and queen are reflected in
the mirror to the artist's right, so
the perspective is that of the king.\0\0The king...watching the artist...paint
the king and the queen...

label: art_00076
text:
Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin (R)
                      \0KTawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century
                                     Gold leaf and ink on paper\0d

label: art_00076_1
text:
This folding screen shows dynamic
brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on
a gold-leaf background.
It is thought to be the masterpiece of
Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo-
period artist.
The simplification of the subjects is
a style that was carried on by
Ogata Kōrin.
It's a style still in use today in the
Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

label: art_00078
text:
A Sunday Afternoon
   on the Island of La Grande Jatte  
         \0KGeorges Seurat, circa 1885, Oil on canvas\0d

label: art_00078_1
text:
Seurat, known as the founder of
neo-impressionism, invented the use
of brightly colored dots.
His method, which does not involve
mixing pigments, took time. This
piece, for instance, took two years.
It shows a crowd enjoying a day off
at the river Seine in France.

label: art_01331
text:
Capitoline Wolf
         　        \0KArtist Unknown, 5th century BCE\0d
 　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　  \0KBronze\0d

label: art_01331_1
text:
This wolf from Roman mythology
raises a pair of twins, along with
some controversy.\0\0The original bronze sculpture of the
wolf is a masterpiece that dates back 
to 5th century BCE.\0\0The twins were added during the
15th century...or so it was thought.\0\0Recent research has given rise to
speculation that the original piece
may be from the 11th or 12th century.\0\0(We will, however, stick with the 5th
century BCE estimate for now.)

label: art_01333
text:
David
      　                  　\0KMichelangelo, circa 1504\0d
　　　　 　　　　　 　　　　　       \0KMarble\0d

label: art_01333_1
text:
Young David glares at his enemies,
sling slung over his shoulder.\0\0It took Michelangelo more than three
years to sculpt this piece.\0\0Close inspection shows heart-
shaped eyes, but that's probably
meant to depict light hitting them.\0\0Hearts didn't have the lovey-dovey
symbolism back then that they do
today.

label: art_01335
text:
Discobolus
     　　         \0KArtist Unknown, 2nd century CE
\0d　　　　　　　　　　　　　            \0KMarble\0d

label: art_01335_1
text:
This ancient Roman statue is based
on the ancient Greek statue crafted
by Myron.
It's a piece that shows the grandeur
of the human body, beautiful from
any angle.

label: art_01337
text:
Jōmon Period "Dogū" Figurine
     Shakōki-dogū                  
      \0KArtist Unknown, 1000-400 BCE, Fired pottery\0d

label: art_01337_1
text:
A mysterious, riveting doll made from
kneaded, unglazed dirt during the
Jōmon period.
Its large round eyes resemble
goggles that intercept light, so its
name should come as no surprise.\0\0"Shakōki" means "light-intercepting
goggles," and a dogū is a small
animal figurine.

label: art_01339
text:
King Kamehameha I
                \0KThomas Ridgeway Gould, circa 1883\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　   \0KBronze\0d

label: art_01339_1
text:
A bronze sculpture of King
Kamehameha I, who founded the
Kingdom of Hawaii in 1810.
Traditionally, the sculpture is
draped with many leis every
year on June 11th.

label: art_01341
text:
Venus de Milo
\0K　　　　　　　          Artist Unknown, circa 130 BCE\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　  　　 \0KMarble\0d

label: art_01341_1
text:
A statue of the Roman goddess of
love and beauty, Venus was found on
the island of Milos.
This beautiful sculpture makes many
wonder what her original pose might
have been.

label: art_01343
text:
Bust of Nefertiti
　　　　                \0KThutmose, circa 1345 BCE
\0d　　　　　　　   　　　　　　　  \0KLimestone\0d

label: art_01343_1
text:
A bust of Nefertiti, whose name
means "the beautiful one has come."\0\0A "royal wife," she was known as one
of the three most beautiful women in
ancient Egypt.\0\0It is not known whether the left eye
is missing because it fell out, or
because it was never completed.

label: art_01345
text:
Nike of Samothrace
　　　　　        \0KArtist Unknown, circa 190 BCE\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　  　　 \0KMarble\0d

label: art_01345_1
text:
A statue of the goddess of victory,
Nike, found on Samothrace. It shows
Nike alighting on the prow of a ship.\0\0Originally found in separate pieces,
it has largely been restored, but the
arms and head are still missing.

label: art_12533
text:
Olmec Colossal Head
  　　　　       \0KArtist Unknown, circa 1000 BCE\0d
  　　　　　　　　　  　　　\0KBasalt, andesite\0d

label: art_12533_1
text:
Giant stone head thought to be
from the ancient Mesoamerican
Olmec civilization.\0\0The larger ones can reach three
meters in height. Scholars think they
only crafted heads, no bodies.

label: art_12535
text:
Rosetta Stone
　　　　　 　          \0K Artist Unknown, 196 BCE\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　 　  \0KGranodiorite\0d

label: art_12535_1
text:
A stone slab found in Rosetta, Egypt
in 1799. Helped efforts to decipher
ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs.\0\0Almost identical text is written in
hieroglyphs at the top, then Demotic
script, and lastly Greek script.

label: art_12537
text:
Houmuwu Ding
　　　　　　          \0KArtist Unknown, 1200 BCE\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　      \0KBronze\0d

label: art_12537_1
text:
This bronze ding from ancient China
is the largest and heaviest ever
found.\0\0The script on the inside suggests
it was created to honor the king's
mother.

label: art_12539
text:
Terracotta Army
　　　　　　　         \0KArtist Unknown, 210 BCE\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　   　  \0KEarthenware\0d

label: art_12539_1
text:
These terracotta warriors were
buried with the first Qin emperor
to protect him in the afterlife.\0\0Nearly 2,000 years later, in 1974,
about 8,000 of them were found.\0\0Each life-sized statue is said to have
been handmade with different poses,
expressions, and clothing.

label: art_12541
text:
The Thinker
　　　　                      \0KAuguste Rodin, 1902\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　 　　  \0KBronze\0d

label: art_12541_1
text:
This bronze sculpture was crafted by
the French sculptor Rodin, known as
the father of modern sculpture.\0\0The incredibly famous original is
located in France. The sculpture was
casted over 20 times.\0\0As such, authentic pieces can be
found all around the world.

label: art_12570
text:
Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin (L)
                      \0KTawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century
                                     Gold leaf and ink on paper\0d

label: art_12570_1
text:
This folding screen shows dynamic
brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on
a gold-leaf background.
It is thought to be the masterpiece of
Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo-
period artist.
The simplification of the subjects is
a style that was carried on by
Ogata Kōrin.
It's a style still in use today in the
Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

label: art_12618
text:
The Starry Night
　                    　  　\0KVincent van Gogh, 1889\0d
　　　　　　　　　　　 　　   \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_12618_1
text:
Van Gogh's signature piece, painted
while he was hospitalized at an
asylum.
This view from his room includes
memories and imaginations. In letters
to friends, the artist called it a failure.

label: art_12619
text:
Vitruvian Man
　                  　\0KLeonardo da Vinci, circa 1487\0d
　　　　　　　　  　　  \0KPen and ink on paper\0d

label: art_12619_1
text:
This drawing is based on the "ideal"
human-body ratio, as stated in
"De architectura."
"De architectura" was a treatise by
Vitruvius, an architect from the early
1st century BCE.

label: art_12621
text:
Ophelia
　                    　　\0KJohn Everett Millais, 1852\0d
　　　　　 　　　　　　 　　  \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_12621_1
text:
Ophelia is a tragic figure in the
Shakespearean play "Hamlet."\0\0There is an otherworldly expression
on her face as she lies unconscious
in a river.
She is surrounded by the beauty of
nature as she floats between life and
death.

label: art_12622
text:
Ajisai Sōkeizu
        　    　　  　　\0KItō Jakuchū, 18th century \0d
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　       \0KDyed silk\0d

label: art_12622_1
text:
A detailed, colorful, and dynamic
piece by Itō Jakuchū, a successful
Kyoto artist in the mid-Edo period.
High-quality paints on silk help it
maintain its brilliant color even now,
200 years after its creation.

label: art_12624
text:
The Fighting Temeraire
                 \0KJoseph Mallord William Turner, 1839\0d
 　　　　　　　　　　　  　　 \0KOil on canvas\0d

label: art_12624_1
text:
A famous piece by Turner, a "master
of light."\0\0It shows an English Navy ship
commanded by Admiral Nelson as it's 
being tugged toward its dismantling.

label: art_12625
text:
Isle of the Dead
　　　　                  　  \0KArnold Böcklin, 1883\0d
 　　　　　　　　　　　　　     \0KOil on wood\0d

label: art_12625_1
text:
A small boat carrying a corpse glides
quietly over a still sea to an island of
graves surrounded by cliffs.
The air of this piece by symbolist
painter Böcklin is chilling, but also
somehow calm.
Böcklin worked here to capture
not what he could see, but some of
humanity's inner contemplations.
